title: 115_hr686
content: The Act may be cited as the "Developing Innovation and Growing the Internet of Things Act" or "DIGIT Act". The Internet of Things (IoT) refers to connected devices, with estimates of over 50 billion devices by 2020. It has the potential to generate trillions in economic activity globally. Businesses in the US can benefit from IoT by developing new products, improving operations, and cutting costs. The US leads in technology supporting the Internet and is well-positioned for IoT development. The United States Government can implement IoT technology to improve public services. The US Senate passed a resolution calling for a national strategy for IoT development. Congress believes IoT policies should benefit businesses, governments, and consumers. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines key terms such as "appropriate committees of Congress," "Commission," "Secretary," "steering committee," and "working group." SEC. 4. FEDERAL WORKING GROUP establishes a working group for IoT development. The Secretary will convene a working group of Federal stakeholders to provide recommendations and a report to Congress on issues related to the Internet of Things. The working group will identify barriers to IoT development, improve coordination among Federal agencies, implement recommendations from the steering committee, and explore how Federal agencies can benefit from using IoT. The working group will examine how Federal agencies can benefit from using Internet of Things technology, the current use of IoT by Federal agencies, their preparedness to adopt IoT in the future, and additional security measures needed to safely use IoT and enhance system resiliency against cyber threats. The Secretary will appoint representatives from various government agencies to the working group, including the Department of Commerce, Department of Transportation, Department of Homeland Security, and others. The working group established by the Department of Energy will consult with nongovernmental stakeholders, including the steering committee, technology manufacturers, subject matter experts from various sectors, businesses of all sizes, think tanks, nonprofits, rural stakeholders, and other relevant experts as determined by the Secretary. Additionally, a steering committee will be established within the Department of Commerce to advise on the matter. The Department of Commerce has established a steering committee to advise the working group on issues related to Federal regulations, spectrum availability for the Internet of Things, and privacy policies. The Secretary shall appoint individuals to enhance security, protect users, and encourage coordination among Federal agencies regarding the Internet of Things. Additionally, small businesses' opportunities and challenges with IoT technology will be addressed, along with international matters affecting the United States. The Secretary will appoint a steering committee with members from various stakeholders outside the Federal Government with expertise in the Internet of Things, including ICT manufacturers, subject matter experts from sectors like agriculture and healthcare, businesses of all sizes, think tanks, academia, nonprofits, consumer groups, and rural stakeholders. The steering committee, consisting of diverse stakeholders with expertise in the Internet of Things, will submit a report to the working group within a year of the Act's enactment. The committee will set its agenda and consider suggestions from the working group in carrying out its duties. The steering committee will terminate when the working group submits the report unless the Secretary files a new charter. The working group must submit a report to Congress within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The working group must submit a report to appropriate committees of Congress including findings, recommendations, progress on implementing recommendations, and actions taken on recommendations made by the steering committee. Any committee of Congress can request a copy of the report. Any committee of Congress can request a copy of the report submitted by the working group to appropriate committees, which includes findings, recommendations, progress on implementing recommendations, and actions taken on recommendations made by the steering committee. SEC. 5. ASSESSING SPECTRUM NEEDS. The Commission, with input from the National Telecommunications and Information Administration, will issue a notice of inquiry to gather public input on current and future spectrum needs for the Internet of Things. This includes assessing available spectrum, identifying regulatory barriers, and understanding the role of licensed and unlicensed spectrum in IoT growth. A report on these findings is due within one year of the Act's enactment. The Commission will submit a report to Congress summarizing comments received in response to the notice of inquiry issued under this Act.
